maml:description.maml:para: Adds an IPv4 vendor or user class to the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
The Add-DhcpServer4Class cmdlet adds an IPv4 vendor or user class to the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
Specifies the name of the vendor or user class being added.
Specifies the type of the class. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor and User.
Specifies data for the vendor or user class. This is the value expected in the request from the DHCP client which belongs to this vendor or user class.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Specifies the description string for the class being added.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Specifies data for the vendor or user class. This is the value expected in the request from the DHCP client which belongs to this vendor or user class.
Specifies the description string for the class being added.
Specifies the name of the vendor or user class being added.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the type of the class. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor and User.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-DhcpServerv4Class -Name "User Class for Lab Computers" -Type User -Data "LabComputers"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds a DHCPv4 user class for lab computers on the DHCP server service.
This example adds a DHCPv4 vendor class for Microsoft Unified Communication clients on the DHCP server service.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves an IPv4 vendor or user class from the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
The Get-DhcpServerv4Class cmdlet retrieves an IPv4 vendor or user class from the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
If only the Type parameter is specified, then all classes of the specified class type are retrieved.
If neither the Name nor the Type parameter is specified, then all of the user and vendor classes are retrieved.
Specifies the name of the vendor or user class being retrieved.
Specifies the type of the class. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor or User.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Specifies the name of the vendor or user class being retrieved.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the type of the class. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor or User.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets all of the DHCPv4 class definitions, including vendor and user, which are present on the DHCP server service running on the computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com.
This example gets all of the DHCPv4 vendor class definitions which are present on the DHCP server service running on the computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com.
This example gets the DHCPv4 vendor class definition for the specified vendor class named MSUCClient on the DHCP server service running on the computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes the IPv4 vendor class or user class from a Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
The Remove-DhcpServerv4Class cmdlet deletes the IPv4 vendor class or user class from a Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
Specifies one or more names for the class or classes to be deleted.
Specifies the type of the class being deleted. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor and User.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the type of the class being deleted. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor and User.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-DhcpServerv4Class -Name "User Class for Lab Computers" -Type User

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example deletes the DHCPv4 user class for the lab computers on the DHCP server service.
This example deletes the DHCPv4 vendor class for the Microsoft Unified Communication clients on the DHCP server service.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies an IPv4 vendor class or user class on the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service with the specified parameters.
The Set-DhcpServerv4Class cmdlet modifies an IPv4 vendor class or user class on the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service with the specified parameters.
The Description or Data parameter must be specified.
Specifies the name of the user or vendor class being modified.
Specifies the type of the class being modified. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor or User.
Specifies the data for the specified vendor or user class. This parameter value is expected in the request from the client belonging to the specified vendor or user class.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Specifies the description string to set on the vendor or user class.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Specifies the data for the specified vendor or user class. This parameter value is expected in the request from the client belonging to the specified vendor or user class.
Specifies the description string to set on the vendor or user class.
Specifies the name of the user or vendor class being modified.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the type of the class being modified. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor or User.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Set-DhcpServerv4Class -Name "User Class for Lab Computers" -Type User -Data "LabComputers"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example sets the data for a DHCPv4 user class for lab computers to LabComputers.
This example sets the data for the DHCPv4 vendor class for Microsoft Unified Communication clients on the DHCP server service to MS-UC-Client.
